text: Is there a plot recipe for Flux.Chain? I started to write one, that already works for Dense and RNN layers (the easy ones), but I would like to know whether there's one already or not.

elements.text: Is there a plot recipe for Flux.Chain? I started to write one, that already works for Dense and RNN layers (the easy ones), but I would like to know whether there's one already or not.

text: No, but we’d appreciate the PR! <https://github.com/FluxML/Flux.jl/issues/1104>

elements.text: No, but we’d appreciate the PR!

text: Great! I was thinking of something more modest, but I can aim for something like that.

elements.text: Great! I was thinking of something more modest, but I can aim for something like that.

text: Doesn’t have to be as “polished” as that. Probably more complex networks will benefit from a more simplified visual layout.

elements.text: Doesn’t have to be as “polished” as that. Probably more complex networks will benefit from a more simplified visual layout.

text: If you haven’t already, you might want to look into Functors.jl (specifically `fmap` or `fcollect`). It might help with walking over the model structure recursively.

elements.text: If you haven’t already, you might want to look into Functors.jl (specifically
). It might help with walking over the model structure recursively.

text: You might also want to look at <https://github.com/FluxML/Flux.jl/pull/1467>, which walks the structure for pretty printing. The two could end up sharing code, or just ideas…

text: Yeah, we can always start simple and grow from there.

elements.text: Yeah, we can always start simple and grow from there.

text: No, I didn’t look at Functors.jl before, but it might indeed help. I will look at the pull request for pretty print too. Thanks!
